bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Vernon W. Lippard, November 19, 1952

div1.p: Hench inquires whether a representative of the Medical School of the University of Virginia would like to place a wreath under Reed's medallion during the dedication of Camp Lazear. Reed graduated from the University of Virginia Medical School in 1869.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Vernon W. Lippard, November 19, 1952
div1.opener:
November 19, 1952
Dr. Vernon W. Lippard, Dean
Medical School
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Doctor Lippard:
div1.p:
On December 3, the anniversary of the birthday of Carlos Finlay, which is
“Physicians' Day in Cuba,” the Cuban Government is memorializing the remains
of Walter Reed's Camp Lazear in Quemados de Marianao. The remains of
Building No. 1 have been repaired, a little park has been made and on a
stone wall will be unveiled several individual bronze medallions, profiles
of Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Carroll, Lazear, Agramonte and Wood. On each
side will be a bronze tablet with the names of the volunteers who served
as guinea pigs.

This will be, I believe, a significant occasion because heretofore there
has been, unfortunately, a considerable feeling of animosity in certain
Cuban circles against those who have honored Reed and his colleagues, the
Cuban viewpoint being that American medicine has ignored the great contribu-
tion of Finlay. Now for the first time the Cuban Government is honoring the
contribution of the Americans by memorializing Camp Lazear in this way. Al-
though I am not certain, it is possible that they may not retain the name
Camp Lazear but may rename the place Parque Finlay. Nevertheless, the
bronze tablets, the dedicatory speeches and so on, will make clear the sig-
nificance of this spot and they are making a small but nevertheless fine
beginning towards a better Cuban-American relationship.

I believe the Cuban Government is planning to send invitations to a number
of Americans and American medical institutions. They have been delayed in
doing this because of some uncertainty as to the final date for the dedica-
tion; but the date has now been set for December 3. I know that General
Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed Hospital, will be there representing
the Surgeon General and a few others are planning to go. The U. S. Embassy
will participate in the ceremonies.

It seems to me that the Americans who attend this ceremony should not go
empty-handed but should respond in a generous way to the gracious intent
of the Cuban Government and medical profession and thus strengthen the
friendship between the Cuban and American medical professions. It occurred
to me that since Major Reed was a graduate of the University of Virginia
Medical School (1869), the Medical School or the Medical Alumni Association
might wish to have a representative of their institution place a wreath or
floral decoration under the medallion of Major Reed on this occasion.
Therefore I am writing you asking whether you would think that would be ap-
propriate. I am writing similar letters to the other half dozen institu-
tions from which those who are mainly to be honored obtained their medical
degrees.

Actually, two additional University of Virginia alumni are being honored; on
one of the tablets will appear the name of General Jefferson Randolph Kean
and that of John J. Moran. Would you care to provide two wreaths, one for
the medallion of Reed and one to be placed under the bronze tablet honoring,
among others, General Kean and Mr. Moran? If you should only wish to pro-
vide one I shall abide by your choice. Incidentally, as you know, Walter
Reed received a second medical degree from the Bellevue Medical College.
They might be willing to provide one wreath and the University of Virginia
could provide the other.

This merely is a request for information as to whether you would think this
gesture appropriate. If so, I shall communicate by cable with the Cuban
authorities and ask them if they will make a place during the ceremony for
the placing of these wreaths.

If you have an alumnus that lives in Havana (and it need not necessarily be
a physician) it would be most appropriate for him to place the wreath at
the proper time; or better yet, if one of your faculty could go (and I fear
that the Cuban Government has no monetary subsidy), that would be excellent
and I will request that a personal invitation be sent for them. If neither
of these are possible, I would myself see to it that the wreath was placed
at the proper time, either by the American Ambassador, by General Streit,
or by myself. However it would be much more effective if a representative
of your institution could do that, providing this suggestion is approved
first by you and then by our Cuban hosts.

Our local florist has told me that he thought a circular wreath of laurel
leaves, perhaps 30 inches in diameter, would be appropriate, perhaps with
a silk ribbon either with the colors of the college or red, white and blue
for the United States, at a cost of perhaps $15 or so. Should you approve
of the general idea, would you care to have your own representative arrange
for the preparation of the wreath in Havana? If not, I should be glad to
help in any way and could either have the half dozen or so wreaths made up
in Havana a day or two ahead, or according to our local florist, they can
be made up in Miami and flown to Havana and delivered to the appropriate
person for placement.

I would appreciate greatly hearing from you at your earliest convenience.
Enclosed please find a photograph of the blue print and a reprint which
will refresh your mind on the significance of Camp Lazear.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: If it seems more appropriate, you might prefer to send a telegraphic
message. The wire could be sent either to His Excellency Dr. Jose Andreu,
El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social or to one of his agents in
this matter, Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana, or Dr. Cesar
Rodriguez Exposito, Secretary, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana.
